B000A59PMO|5.0|For those looking for the true heir to Buffy the Vampire Slayer in terms of a sharp script and snappy dialogue look no further than the UPN show Veronica Mars. Not since Sunnydale dropped into a deep chasm has television seen such a fabulous ensemble of talented young actors deliver such inventive dialogue in intelligent, darkly humorously directed fare.<br /><br />In what is possibly one of the best shows on television today Veronica Mars first season aired in fall 2004 and fast developed a devoted fan following.<br /><br />For me Tuesday nights became the most anticipated TV night of the week and I could not get enough of the show or its hot star Kristen Bell. It quickly shot up the rankings on my TiVo season pass where it now sits at number one and my Kristen Bell TiVo wish-list was set to auto-record so I would not miss any program in which she was featured. I remember the anger when my local UPN station decided to air a baseball game instead of one episode - never have I felt more like putting pen to paper to express my displeasure with a programming decision.<br /><br />So what is this show that induces such passion? It's a detective show, no it's a romantic drama, or is it a dark comedy? Well, in reality it is all of this and more. Set in the California city of Neptune, it paints the picture of a society split between the have's such as the rich Kane family or movie star Aaron Echoll's wife and children and the have-nots (notably title character Veronica Mars and her friends Wallace and Weevil).<br /><br />Veronica is the daughter of Keith Mars, the former Sheriff, who was ousted after accusing millionaire software businessman Jake Kane of murdering his daughter (and Veronica's best friend) Lilly.<br /><br />Now a private detective Keith is still investigating the murder and determined in his conviction that the man in jail for the murder is innocent. He is supported in this belief by his daughter a fact which has made her a social outcast from the popular clique to which she once belonged.<br /><br />The murder-mystery and the mystery to a rape that occurred before the show opens both serve as the season-long story arc. But, as Veronica continues her investigation each episode involves the investigation into a lesser mystery. From stolen poker winnings to missing school mascots to  missing dogs and busting a fake ID card ring, Veronica (with the help of Wallace, Mac and assorted other misfits) must navigate a world of secret societies, shady Kane security personnel and a largely hostile school environment.<br /><br />In addition to the great script the other strength of the show is in assembling a wonderful ensemble of young actors. Led by Kristen Bell who as Veronica outdo's Buffy in the dry humor department, and ably supported by Canadian actor Enrico Colantoni as Keith Mars, the two really display a true father-daughter affection for each other which apparently was true off-screen as well. In addition to this dynamic there is also Percy Daggs III as Veronica's best friend (and cohort in her investigations) Wallace. Teddy Dunn plays tortured with some secret that he struggles to keep hidden as Veronica's ex-boyfriend Duncan Kane and Jason Dohring appears as Logan, the bad-boy rich kid son of actor Aaron (who is played by Harry Hamlin of LA Law and Clash of the Titans fame). Completing the talented young cast is Francis Capra as biker bad-boy Weevil.<br /><br />Not to spoil the ending of the show for anyone who missed it on its initial run over fall 2004 to spring 2005 or the reruns of select episodes over the summer of 2005, this show needs to be seen to be believed. Sure I am a diehard fan of the show, but I defy any viewer not to became charmed by the drama, romance, humor and well drawn characters. Yes, the mysteries are solved but a lot of the fun comes in the journey towards those last two episodes of the season.<br /><br />On this DVD set of six discs we are promised deleted scenes, a gag reel and extended takes. The release was supposed to have already happened, but was pushed back when fans complained that they didn't want a bare-bones release. I'm happy though because now it is scheduled to arrive on my birthday - Oct. 11. What a fantastic birthday present!<br /><br />Personally I cannot wait for Season 2 that starts Sept. 28, 2005. Creator Rob Thomas has promised us a great new mystery and besides that question that burns the most is the one that Thomas left us with at the end of season one - just who was it at the door?eady happened, but was pushed back when fans complained that they didn't want a bare-bones release. B00008ADPF|5.0|The Up Side: Nickelback are one of the very few bands who can balance loud, rock driven guitars with sweet pop-like melodies, and actually pull it off. When you're not rocking out, you'll be singing along at the top of your lungs. The Long Road is no exception to Nickelback's award winning, medium heavy sound. Song for song, TLR is without a single weak link, making for a complete and rewarding listen. Singles like Someday and Figured You Out are obvious smash hits, but when a band can create an entire 40+ minutes of quality material, equal or greater than said singles, you know they've got talent! The Long Road really is quality radio-rock for all moods, and the hooks are out of this world!! <br /> <br />The Down Side: Jealous critics/musicians, usually those without much talent, are quick to judge such a tight sound, and that is exactly what happened with Nickelback and The Long Road. Bad press for such a good record boggles my mind, because although The Long Road isn't exactly a favorite with various web zines and online music reviewers, it truly is a timeless rock and roll album.  <br /> <br />The Flip Side: Nickelback have a sound and style that work for them, and they aren't ready to give that up just yet. So while everyone else is making drastic changes to their sound just to keep up with trends, Nickelback keep it real.   <br /> <br />The Conclusion: The Long Road will have you singing along for years to come, and if you liked Silver Side Up, chances are you'll like this one even more. <br /> <br />The End.

B00005JLZN|1.0|The only way for me to make my point is to possibly give away the ending. I promise to watch my step, but if you want to be surprised at the lame \\"twist\\" then stop reading.<br /><br />Alright, here it is. David Gale, a devout anti-death-penalty advocate finds himself on death row for the murder of his close friend and one-time fling. It seems like an open and shut case, but David is swearing his innocence and says he's being framed, which catches the attention of \\"Bitsey\\" Bloom (now there's a name that just commands respect)<br /><br />Anyway, the film chases its own tail for a little and, after a while, it's insinuated that David may have made himself LOOK guilty just to attract attention to the cause by becoming some kind of martyr.<br /><br />See ... here's the problem, two-thirds of the way into the movie the film's story paints itself into a corner it can't get out of. What we're left with as the film begins to reach its 'big reveal' are two different directions the plot can take to resolve itself:<br /><br />1. David is actually innocent of the crime, and tampered with the evidence to make himself look guilty - This doesn't make any sense because he's disproving his own argument. If he subverted the justice system to make himself look guilty and he's then convicted, isn't that proof that the system works? 'The System' isn't cheating Gale, Gale's cheating the system by tampering with his own trial to get the verdict he wants. How can this then be held up as proof that the death-penalty is wrong?<br /><br />2. David actually did it - In which case he was convicted of murder and is sitting on death row. This, if true, means we've wasted two hours of our time watching Kevin Spacey over-act.<br /><br />The thing is, neither of these scenarios work. In either option, David SHOULD be on death row; he either doctored his trail to get himself there or he's actually a murderer.<br /><br />The film was CLEARLY trying to make a statement about the injustice of capital punishment, but in the process only managed to (pardon the pun) shoot itself in the foot and discredit its own argument.pun) shoot itself in the foot and discredit its own argument.

B000068TPN|5.0|From the first scene, \\"We Were Soldiers\\" puts you into the thick of action with all the realism that could be mustered. In the first scene, a viewer could find themselves a bit overwhelmed by the realism of the combat, as well as the blood in some places.<br /><br />Once through the first scene, what follows is a movie that takes you on an emotional rollercoaster ride through the lives and loves of the men of the 1st Air Cav. They were the first unit to engage the North Vietnamese forces in a major battle and along with being outnumbered, they were also testing a fledgling style of battle using helicopters.<br /><br />The movie inserts you into the lives of the men and also their families and wives. You will find yourself fully immersed into their loves, joys, pains and problems. The story fully engages you with the emotions of losing husbands overseas, losing friends, and losing men. It is a powerful movie and a powerful story. if you watch it in groups, keep a supply of tissues nearby.<br /><br />In terms of the battle scenes, they are violent and realistic, however they fit well into the context and they show something of what it must have been like to be in the middle of an intense battle. This is not surprising, as Hal Moore, (played by Gibson in the movie), consulted on this movie.<br /><br />All in all, this is among the best war movies I have seen, both for the powerful story it tells and the sheer level of action that it shows. It will pull at your heart, and do it powerfully. I unreservedly recommend this film to anyone.
B000002G8H|5.0|\\"Slowhand\\" is one of Eric Clapton's finest albums to be released during the late '70s and rightfully so!!!<br /><br />Clapton's stellar musical chops combined with a solid backup band makes for what is undoubtedley a signature album.<br /><br />The opening trio of \\"Cocaine\\", \\"Wonderful Tonight\\" and \\"Lay Down Sally\\" have gone on to become Clapton standards with the latter two tracks being amongst his best original compositions.<br /><br />Elsewhere on \\"Slowhand\\" are standout tracks such as \\"Next Time You See Her\\", the blues-driven \\"Mean Old Frisco\\", the flowing instrumental of \\"Peaches and Diesel\\" and the extended funk-rock jams of \\"The Core\\" which, in addition to Clapton's solid guitar work, features a superb vocal performance from singer Marcy Levy and a great sax lead from sessionman Mel Collins (who is actually a former member of the prog-rock giants King Crimson).<br /><br />Since its release in 1977, \\"Slowhand\\" has stood the test of time as a staple of classic rock. The album still has a fresh vibrant sound that doesn't sound a bit outdated or disappointing. With Clapton's powerful guitar and vocal work, great musicianship from his band and Glyn Johns' solid production, there is little wonder why the title of this album has become a nickname for Clapton himself. One listen to \\"Slowhand\\" proves that Eric Clapton has earned the title rightly.

B000AL730O|5.0|Chaos and Creation in the Backyard sounds like a little bit of everything from Beatles to Wings to solo McCartney. It echoes most of what he has written, so it covers a wide range of his own signature style and sound. Much like McCartney and McCartney II he plays just about all of the instruments, which makes Chaos an even more accomplished work of art. I hear bits from Revolver, Magical Mystery Tour, White Album, Abbey Road, Ram, London Town, Tug of War and the classic Flaming Pie. The spirits of George Harrison, John Lennon and Linda are very present throughout which is a tribute to them.  It is very well produced thanks to Nigel Godrich. George Martin should be proud of him. I am also a huge Radiohead fan and I hear some of the slightly darker moods and feelings that are evident in their songs. For instance, the major/minor chord sequence on How Kind of You sounds a lot like Motion Picture Soundtrack from Kid A, right down to the same accordian. Maybe Nigel had a little to do with that as well. I will say that Chaos is as important as OK Computer or Revolver without hesitation. There are many layers that aren't evident upon the first or second listen. You can't absorb it all without hearing it multiple times. Credit to Nigel for telling Paul the truth about what he should do. He pulled no punches with McCartney and that's a good thing. I'm going to the show in Philly on Sept 23rd. B000AL730O|3.0|I'd like to start by saying I think McCartney is a musical genius, a true artist, a minstrel of old.  But, sadly, this subdued and introspective album is not one of his better efforts.  I've bought just about everything by him through the years, even his lesser known singles like \\"Sally G\\" and \\"It's Not True,\\" and it seems as if all the criticism of the past has made him change in some way.  Now, it seems, he concentrates more on his lyrics than his melodies -- and he is the undisputed master of melody.  \\"Fine Line\\" is the only passable \\"hit\\" on the album, although I really like the insightful \\"Jenny Wren,\\" the playful \\"English Tea,\\" and the seasoned \\"At the Mercy.\\"  The album undoubtedly features a more mature and sagacious McCartney, although many of the tunes sound much alike.  And, regrettably, most of them are fillers.  George Harrison once wondered how McCartney could come up with so many diverse melodies and never seemingly run out.  Well, let's hope he still has a few melodies left.  Combined with more intelligent and mature lyrics, it could make for a great future album.
B000002ILG|5.0|It's pretty obvious what's going on here.  One day in the 80s, a record producer living in a plush apartment in Manhattan barked out orders to one of his underlings: \\"find me a beautiful rock singer, a blond guy, someone that will make the girls go crazy.  Also get me an out-of-this-world guitarist.  I don't care what the guy looks like or how ugly he is.  He can look like a vampire for all I care.  The important thing is that he can play guitar solos that will confound everyone--even the editors of Guitar World magazine.  Finally, get me a drummer and a bassist with big hair.  I want them both to have mullets.  Otherwise, I don't care too much about them so long as they don't get in the way of the beautiful vocalist and the freak guitarist.\\"     The underling assiduously carried out his task and found, respectively, Mike Tramp, Vito Bratta, Greg D'Angelo and James Lomenzo.  Tramp was spotted walking down the street with one supermodel on each arm.  \\"Can you sing?\\" the underling asked.  \\"Sure,\\" Tramp said.  White Lion had its singer.  The underling discovered Bratta at a guitar shop.  Bratta was trying out a guitar.  500 people were watching in awe.  The guy was like Yngwie Malmsteen on steroids.  Pinch harmonics, sweep arpeggios, 30-note melodic sequences in half a second, nothing was too difficult for this fretboard wizard. \\"Are you in a band?\\" the underling asked.  \\"No,\\" Bratta replied.  White Lion had its guitarist.  D'Angelo and Lomenzo were recruited at a movie theater.  The two were sitting together.  Patrons seated behind them were complaining: \\"we can't see the screen because of that wall of hair.\\"   \\"Perfect,\\" thought the underling.  Once it developed that the two understood what drums and a bass were, White Lion had its drummer and bassist.      Now, you might expect that a group thrown together in this fashion would have no chemistry and would not be good.  That is what I would expect.  But this group rules!  Somehow, against all odds, the record producer's project was successful!      Here you have some of the finest rock songs to come out of the mid/late 80s.  You have amazing sing-along choruses, and blistering guitar solos that will make you shake your head in amazement.  Surprisingly enough, this album also contains coherent songs that actually stand on their own as songs.  I probably don't need to explain the merits of \\"Wait\\" or \\"When the Children Cry\\" to you, but you also should know that three other songs on this album (\\"Lonely Nights,\\" \\"Sweet Little Loving\\" and \\"Tell me\\") are also exceptional.  Buy this album and relive the 80s.  See for yourself that it is possible for a formulaic group to become a great group provided that they have the right attitude and are talented enough to pull it off.

So I pondered it for a while and decided that, while there are certainly aspects to respect, in the over-simplified classification of good-or-bad, I still have to lean toward the bad.    When done well, excessively long, silent shots can work very well to subtly further a story or emotion while drawing the viewer into its rhythm. I cite \\"Goodbye Dragon Inn\\" as an example. While I appreciated the desperation and loneliness conveyed by the lingering shots in Bunny, after a while I felt as though they had nothing more to convey, and they worked to the detriment of their initial impact. B000AJJNPY|5.0|Okay, call me crazy. I live in the so-called live music capital of the world here in Austin and what moment I anticipated the most here of recent weeks is the release of Takk by Sigur Ros. After watching the devastation of New Orleans, my favorite city on earth by the forces of nature and neglect by man I've had as much reality as I can stomach for now. What cure could be more apropos than the surreal, other worldly beauty of the new Sigur Ros - Takk CD?  Nothing could prepare me for the chilling, stark, and absolutely gorgeous songs that have been crafted with loving care. So keen has my escape been premiered that I went out in subsequent weeks and purchased the two The Album Leaf CDs - Seal Beach (reissued with the live tracks while on tour with Sigur Ros) and In A Safe Place (backed with Sigur Ros in a recording studio setting) to help satiate this chomping at the bit restlessness. It worked. Those excellent discs in their own way helped stir the stew and kneed the bread for the major musical threads now coursing their way through my subconscious as the Takk CD remains on repeat. As I slumber to the musical equivalent of adult Neverland tales I am thankful for the timeless quality and careful attention paid to every detail. The need for something ethereal and not grounded is overwhelming at present and they serve it up in abundance. This is like nothing else around and I hope that nothing else ever is. Their previous albums () and Agaetis Byrjun are Icelandic skyscrapers also, but Takk makes the huge leap forward to solidifying their unique qualities as substantial and lasting. I stand, no make that floored and speechless. I can no longer wipe the smile off my face as I can crimp the wings of my soaring spirit.<br /><br />The superb packaging and art design of CD pack is reminiscent of an old English first edition Victorian novel. Perfect in every aspect. Those willing to drop their guard and notions, there's plenty to be blown away by. Experiment soon. The effects are chilling, raucous, ambient, and melodic beyond compare.fects are chilling, raucous, ambient, and melodic beyond compare.

B000AJJNPY|5.0|What is there left to say about Icelandic four piece Sigur Ros that hasn't been said before? <br /> <br />In the ten years since their conception they've continually managed to astound, encapsulate and bewilder all in the space of one piece of music - no point saying song as Sigur Ros don't strictly do \\"songs\\" - creating the perfect accompaniment to any kind of celluloid moment from Tolkien-esque wizardry to Barry like thrillers. <br /> <br />The critics have loved them from day one, and finally with `Takk' getting the Hollywood seal of approval from people like Tom Cruise and Gwyneth Paltrow it seems like the name checks could pay dividends when the sales-related pay cheques arrive. <br /> <br />Whereas their last long player `()' bordered slightly on the overblown and pretentious, `Takk' is more of a return to the grandiose, dream theatre of 1999's `Agaetis Byrjun' with more expensive production thrown in for good measure, and straight from the word \\"Fara\\", where the title track effortlessly glides into the elegiac nursery rhyme of `Glosoli', `Takk' sounds like it could be Sigur Ros' most accessible record to date. As `Glosoli' builds and builds into the sort of climax usually reserved for volcanic eruptions, the aftermath is like a sweet feeling of relief, as the quietly moving `Hoppipolla' follows suit, almost soothing in contrast to it's precursor's dynamic explosion. <br /> <br />It's hard to imagine what inspired Sigur Ros to write this album but if `Se Lest' is anything to go by, then maybe six months locked up in a feral cat sanctuary was one of their between albums vacations?  <br /> <br />The hushed lullaby of `Saeglopur' and graceful ambience of `Milano' set the scene for the `Loveless' defined orchestral fervour of `Gong', a monolith of simplistic notes and chord changes with more layers than a wedding cake and a penchant for unexpected twists and turns that only Hockenheim can match in it's complexity. If dream weaving were an art form, then Sigur Roswould be the master tutors par excellence. <br /> <br />By the time `Heysatan' closes the record, it's almost time to open one's eyes and return to the land of the living.  <br /> <br />`Takk' raises the bar for any of Sigur Ros' post-ethereal soundscape contemporaries. There isn't really anything else you can say about Sigur Ros or this record that the music doesn't translate in itself, and in my book, that is possibly the highest compliment you can pay any artist past or present.
B000002ADT|5.0|I don't think I can add anything more profound or noteworthy regarding this record than what has already been posted by the 500 plus reviewers before me. I came into jazz late in life, having grown up listening to rock and roll through my late 30's. It was around the time of my 40th birthday that I first heard \\"So What\\" on a jazz radio station, and I was immediately drawn to this recording like a magnet. I raced into a record store and bought \\"Kind of Blue.\\" I became an instant convert to jazz, almost overnight. I have probably listened to this record thousands of times during periods of both sorrow and joy. This record has kept me good company over the years. Interestingly, I seem to find something new and interesting with each repeated listening. Kind of Blue is a classic piece of art that certainly belongs in any record collection. The cast of characters who created this timeless recording reads like a who's who list of the greatest jazz musicians of the 20th century. The playing from Davis, Coltrane, Evans, et al is simply superb. Kind of Blue is arguably the single best jazz recording ever released. What more can I say? If you don't have it, go out and buy it today....This is essential music...

B000AL730Y|4.0|This CD sounds different than any other McCartney album to date. The instrumental interludes are more atmospheric. Some songs such as Riding to Vanity Fair are darker in sound utilizing minor keys. Overall this is a much more mature and subdued McCartney. Occasionally the mood harkens back. English Tea sounds like it would been at home in the Sgt. Pepper days. McCartney acknowledges George Harrison's influence in Friends to Go a song with nice Beatlesqu background vocals. Other influences he admits to in the DVD are Randy Newman (Anyway) and Charlie Chaplain (Too Much Rain). There are elements that seem to owe something to Coldplay McCarneys favorite contemporary band. The only song that I would skip over is A Certain Softness, a song that is too lightweight for this collection. The CD would have been better if \\"Softness\\" had been replaced by Comfort of Love, The song offered as a download to those who get this CD at Best Buy (Does anyone know if Best Buy the only place this download is offered?). Comfort of Love is more catchy than most of the songs on the CD and could easily have been released as a single. <br />Following a courant trend there is a hidden track at the end of the CD, an unnamed instrumental. Mcartney Plays most of the instruments, with his tour band playing only on Follow Me, and then only in minor rolles. <br />Overall this is not the catchy pop we expect from McCartney, but songs that creep up on you and get under your skin with their deceptive complexity.  <br />The best part of the DVD is the making of section where Paul and Producer Nigel Godrich talk about the development of the songs. This section also has a segment of Paul presenting a new song at the Glastonbury Festival. This made me wish they had included more from the Glastonbury performance. The animated line drawings part is only worth one watch. It's not really animated but the drawings from the booklet being panned with instrumental backing tracks playing. <br />The in studio performance video for Fine Line is OK. <br />

B00000J7SS|5.0|While jazz has had such a great evolution since it began in the early 20th Century, from traditional, to swing, to be-bop, the very late sixties to the early seventies brought up a very important progression in the genre thus far. Fusion was something that some have argued is what really defines jazz, this was one of the first that actually established fusion for what we know of today. Along with his other album \\"In a Silent Way\\", that came out just a couple years prior to \\"Bitches Brew, Miles Davis created a very unique musical form, that many have labelled these albums especially \\"Brew\\" as being utterly genius. So what defines fusion? Miles being a fan of much of the \\"pop\\" music that debuted in the sixties combined that with jazz, creating a \\"fusion\\" of sorts. Davis combines his talent with other important jazz musicians talent as the basis for \\"Brew\\". Many of the musicians who would go on to form their own pioneering fusion bands such as Return to Forever, The Weather Report and The Mahavishnu Orchestra are present on this album including, Chick Corea, Joe Zawinul, Wayne Shorter, John McLaughlin, Lenny White and Jack DeJohnette among others. The music on this album is nothing but fascinating. While most songs are pretty lengthy in time, each musician has their time in the spotlight, that's not to say that Miles is thrown in the background, most of the solos is played by the Davis. It is easy to see why many conservative jazz musicians didn't like the album, the songs are very different sounding, even more so to fusion we hear today like John Scofield, various Chick Corea bands and Pat Metheny for example. The music can get some getting used to, but the music will eventually overcome and one will find themselves in amazement. The title cut is probably the most interesting on the album. With its' almost pulsating introduction and atmospheric, very experimental keyboard sounds, until Miles enters playing a very haunting almost fanfare sounding lick that introduces the song. There are many other important highlights that one hears on \\"Bitches Brew\\", from the techmicality of \\"Spanish Key\\" to the closing of the album with \\"Feio\\", is all apart of a very genius album. Although to some there may be better fusion bands and albums out there, it really doesn't get any better than this. \\"Bitches Brew\\" is an album that any musicians or music listeners should consider, for it is such an important landmark in the world of music that helped to create such an important genre that includes everything from Sting to Smooth Jazz to The Weather Report.

B0009NSE1K|5.0|Yet another Clutch album. Yet another masterpiece. Talk about groove. Talk about blues. Talk about rock. Damn. Fans of this band will know that a Clutch album is always a must-have, and this is no exception. How they keep making such quality material after so long and with very little or no mainstream success, is beyond me..though very popular as a cult-band, they're hardly heard on the radio or played/talked about on MTV. (And that's the way the band wants to keep it, it seems)    This album kind of snuck up on me, as i only just recently heard about it's release and so i went out to buy it about a week ago. Neil Fallon's vocals don't sound *as* harsh as on previous albums, at least to me, but they may have to do with the great production on this album. The trademark crazy rhymes/lyrics are still there though, delivered with the same style of old. This album i think will grow on alot of people. That is to say, that it'll take a little while to get into. For me, it did..it took a few days for it all to come together. But once it does, you'll be listening to it quite frequently.    So here you have it.. Clutch. New Album. 14 songs. 55 minutes long. If you're already a fan, it's a no-brainer. For new fans, i'd even start with this. Maybe try the samples first and see what you think. This is, yet again, another really enjoyable album by Clutch. It's definitely worth your time if you're even slightly into Rock or Hard Rock/Blues.     I'm already wondering how their next album will sound like..

B000006E4C|5.0|If you have ever heard of Steve Reich, it may have been in a Music Appreciation class in college. His genre is minimalism, considered by some to be &#34;America's classical music.&#34; If you have never heard this kind of music before, it could really bother you. This music has a whole different philosophy underlying it. What is music supposed to do for you? Popular classical music typically has strong form, and seeks to provide the listener with many types of variety in melody and chord-progression. Minimalism intentionally does away with a lot of that. In Steve Reich's music, rhythm is very important, and in 18, continuous pulses, melodic patterns, crescendos and decrescendos all swirl and dovetail. Repetition is used to create a tonal &#34;picture&#34; for you to soak in as subtle variations are introduced and eventually fade out. The result is colorfully impressionistic, and at times jazzy.

B000002LPD|4.0|In 1991 Van Halen released their ninth studio album \\"For Unlawful Carnal Knowledge.\\" It was their third album with lead singer Sammy Hagar and their first collaboration with producer Ted Templeman since \\"1984\\" (1984). Perhaps because Templeman was back at the helm as co-producer, \\"For Unlawful Carnal Knowledge\\" rocks a lot harder than its two processors \\"5150\\" (1986) and \\"OU812\\" (1988).<br /><br />Released in the waning days of pop-metal, right before the onset of the alternative rock boom of '91, \\"For Unlawful Carnal Knowledge\\" eschews many of the commercial aspects of \\"5150\\" and \\"OU812.\\" While the album overall is quite radio/MTV friendly, the album lacks the ballads and keyboards of Van Hagar's first two albums.<br /><br />I find \\"For Unlawful Carnal Knowledge\\" to sound more like Sammy Hagar's 80s Geffen albums-\\"Standing Hampton\\" (1981), \\"Three Lock Box\\" (1982) and \\"VOA\\" (1984) as opposed  to the early Van Hagar albums or classic Roth-era Van Halen. In short, \\"For Unlawful Carnal Knowledge\\" is meat-and-potatoes, no nonsense AOR rock n' roll.<br /><br />Van Halen and Hagar's third collaboration saw all involved return to their roots, more or less. The band opted to make a great hard-rock album, as opposed to a more commercial adult-contemporary one.<br /><br />While \\"5150\\" and \\"OU812\\" were strong, the band hadn't sounded so good in years. Unlike \\"OU812,\\" you can actually hear Michael Anthony's bass. Drummer Alex Van Halen didn't play on some lame drum machine (as he did on \\"5150\\") and the tone and mix sounds much better here than it did on \\"5150\\" and \\"OU812.\\" Sammy Hagar's lyrics showed more depth and he, as always, gives a fine vocal performance. And, it goes without saying that Eddie Van Halen sounds as great as ever, contributing at least a few screeching solos to each song.  And while the band certainly rocks harder here than they did on the two proceeding albums, the song-writing was still strong. The album is filled with good hooks and sing-along melodies. Although some songs are better than others, there really isn't any filler on \\"For Unlawful Canal Knowledge.\\"<br /><br />Up to this point in the band's career, the overall tone of Van Halen's catalogue was celebratory. \\"For Unlawful Carnal Knowledge\\" represents the last album of that era. It was really the last feel-good Van Halen album. Although \\"Balance\\" (1995) is a fine album, it was a distinctly dark album released in a musical landscape that had abolished all traces of 80s rock (Van Halen, KISS, Aerosmith, were among those spared). \\"Van Halen 3\\" (1998) saw Van Halen experiment and venture out in a way that Van Halen's fans almost unanimously rejected. \\"For Unlawful Carnal Knowledge\\" was released at a time when bands like Poison and Warrant enjoyed mainstream popularity and huge commercial successes. Much like \\"Balance\\" reflected the dark musical landscape of the times, \\"For Unlawful Carnal Knowledge\\" reflected the sunny careless days of Beverley Hills 90210 and George H.W. Bush's \\"1000 points of light.\\" That is not to say that \\"For Unlawful Carnal Knowledge\\" lacks substance, as the band shows depth in songs like \\"Right Now\\" and \\"Judgment Day.\\" But the album's overall tone is bright and optimistic, unlike \\"Balance\\" which is pessimistic and dark.<br /><br />\\"For Unlawful Carnal Knowledge\\" opens up strong with the arena-rock anthem \\"Poundcake\\" which was the band's most rocking song since \\"Panama\\" (from \\"1984\\"). \\"<br /><br />\\"Judgment Day,\\" has a great groove and Hagar shows some depth with his questioning of the religious right and televangelists.<br /><br />Although \\"Spanked\\" is mid-tempo, it never gets tepid. The lyrics are a little stupid, but stupid in a nave, Sammy Hagar/jock rock kind-of-way, so I'll give Hagar a pass.<br /><br />\\"Runaround\\" is just a fun song that keeps up the momentum.<br /><br />\\"Pleasure Dome,\\" whose meaning is obscure, is said to be a song about masturbation. This song has an almost mystical vibe to it, with a really cool drum roll-it'sdifferent for Van Halen and a really cool song.<br /><br />Although the title of \\"In and Out\\" may lead one to believe it's just another stupid song about sex, it actually is far more substantive than that. The major point of the song being that life is hard and you have to pay debts throughout life.<br /><br />Although not an album highlight, the catchy mid-paced \\"Man on a Mission\\" keeps the album going.<br /><br /> \\"The Dream is Over\\" is a personal favorite of mine. It has a great infectious groove, catchy sing-along chorus, and killer solos-in short, it has all the ingredients of the perfect Van Halen song. It's a song about letting go, of letting a dream die and moving on. \\"The Dream is Over\\" demonstrates Hagar's everyman wisdom at its best.<br /><br />The album's huge hit and centerpiece \\"Right Now\\" introduced \\"Generation Y\\" to Van Halen. \\"Right Now\\" should silence Van Halen's detractors who claim that the band never had any songs with substance.  Sammy Hagar's lyrics may not be witty and clever like Roth's, or profound like Lennon and Dylan's. However, as previously stated, Hagar's lyrics do encompass an \\"everyman wisdom\\"-a blue-collar insight that you learn though the school-of-hard-knocks, as opposed to reading Plato. \\"Right Now\\" shows this kind of insight. And while the song's theme-live in the present, forget about the past, don't worry about the future-may seem obvious, Hagar's lyrics are clever and memorable. He tells the theme in a way that puts life in perspective.<br /><br /> \\"316\\" is a short lullaby-like acoustic instrumental tribute to Eddie Van Halen's son, Wolfgang.<br /><br />I see the upbeat \\"Top of the World\\" as a sequel to \\"Dreams\\" (from \\"5150\\"), but with guitar in place of synthesizers.  This upbeat rocker is strong enough and a good way to conclude the album.<br /><br />In all honesty, \\"For Unlawful Carnal Knowledge\\" can't touch the classic first six Van Halen albums-but very few ones can. Nor is \\"For Unlawful Carnal Knowledge\\" quite as strong as some of Sammy Hagar's solo albums-\\"Danger Zone\\" (1980), \\"Standing Hampton\\" (1981), and \\"Marching to Mars\\" (1997)-as some examples.  Still, although Van Halen purists will never accept anything after \\"1984,\\" \\"For Unlawful Carnal Knowledge\\" is a strong album that should please most fans., with a really cool drum roll-it's different for Van Halen and a really cool song.  <br /> <br />Although the title of \\"In and Out\\" may lead one to believe it's just another stupid song about sex, it actually is far more substantive than that. The major point of the song being that life is hard and you have to pay debts throughout life.  <br /> <br />Although not an album highlight, the catchy mid-paced \\"Man on a Mission\\" keeps the album going. <br /> <br /> \\"The Dream is Over\\" is a personal favorite of mine. It has a great infectious groove, catchy sing-along chorus, and killer solos-in short, it has all the ingredients of the perfect Van Halen song. It's a song about letting go, of letting a dream die and moving on. \\"The Dream is Over\\" demonstrates Hagar's everyman wisdom at its best.    <br /> <br />The album's huge hit and centerpiece \\"Right Now\\" introduced \\"Generation Y\\" to Van Halen. \\"Right Now\\" should silence Van Halen's detractors who claim that the band never had any songs with substance.  Sammy Hagar's lyrics may not be witty and clever like Roth's, or profound like Lennon and Dylan's. However, as previously stated, Hagar's lyrics do encompass an \\"everyman wisdom\\"-a blue-collar insight that you learn though the school-of-hard-knocks, as opposed to reading Plato. \\"Right Now\\" shows this kind of insight. And while the song's theme-live in the present, forget about the past, don't worry about the future-may seem obvious, Hagar's lyrics are clever and memorable. He tells the theme in a way that puts life in perspective. <br /> <br /> \\"316\\" is a short lullaby-like acoustic instrumental tribute to Eddie Van Halen's son, Wolfgang.  <br /> <br />I see the upbeat \\"Top of the World\\" as a sequel to \\"Dreams\\" (from \\"5150\\"), but with guitar in place of synthesizers.  This upbeat rocker is strong enough and a good way to conclude the album.  <br /> <br />In all honesty, \\"For Unlawful Carnal Knowledge\\" can't touch the classic first six Van Halen albums-but very few ones can. Nor is \\"For Unlawful Carnal Knowledge\\" quite as strong as some of Sammy Hagar's solo albums-\\"Danger Zone\\" (1980), \\"Standing Hampton\\" (1981), and \\"Marching to Mars\\" (1997)-as some examples.  Still, although Van Halen purists will never accept anything after \\"1984,\\" \\"For Unlawful Carnal Knowledge\\" is a strong album that should please most fans.  <br /> <br />   <br />

B000A42QIU|5.0|This album, Very and its much more rare companion, Very Relentless, can be summed up in the Pet Shop Boys' own words (one of the lyrics taken from the song Yesterday When I was Mad) -- they've 'both made such a little go a very long way'. A very long way, indeed.<br /><br />All of the songs on this album have the same feel -- the same texture, the same lyrical quality, the same 'groove' if you will -- which is remarkable for a collection of different songs, from ballads to a roaring remake of the Village People's Go West (a song Toyota still uses occasionally in advertising -- listen for the backing music). One would almost swear that the actual Village People are making up the chorus as Neil Tennant's high-pitched, flat voice calls out 'Life is peaceful there' as the gruff, deep voices growl, GO WEST!<br /><br />All the songs are dancable (not true of all the songs on all the albums) -- the videos which accompany this album all have the same computer-generated motion and costume and background (someone in the Pet Shop Boys camp obviously had recently discovered computer-generated graphics and animation and decided to have some fun!). I was frankly a bit disappointed with the videos, because the idea was original, but it was the same idea for each video (and we fans are used to stylish, original videos for each song).<br /><br />This album will please Pet Shop Boys fans; it may find a good home with electronic/disco music fans. As with all Pet Shop Boys songs, listen to the lyrics -- they are witty and thoughtful -- the song Dreaming of the Queen actually plays on a recurrent nightmare/stress dream that the average Brit would have but Americans don't -- the stress that the Queen drops by for a visit when you're not ready (either undressed, or dirty house, &c.) -- probably the closest equivalent stress dream in American terms would be the test-anxiety pop-quiz-you-haven't-studied-for dream.<br /><br />Other songs include the poignant The Theatre, in which one can sense the frustration of struggling artists as they watch their more successful compatriots pass by; To speak is a sin, recapturing a word from a previous hit, It's a sin, something the no-longer Roman Catholic Tennant likes to muse over now and again; the first semi-hit Can you forgive her, a crashing, triumphant, psychological song that reinforces the ambiguous sexuality of this duo (later to be made less so).<br /><br />So, pay attention to the lyrics, and have a Very Very good listen.can sense the frustration of struggling artists as they watch their more successful compatriots pass by; To speak is a sin, recapturing a word from a previous hit, It's a sin, something the no-longer Roman Catholic Tennant likes to muse over now and again; the first semi-hit Can you forgive her, a crashing, triumphant, psychological song that reinforces the ambiguous sexuality of this duo (later to be made less so). <br /> <br />So, pay attention to the lyrics, and have a Very Very good listen. <br /> <br />

B0007GAEW6|1.0|People desperately want there to be a resurgence of epic rock music and for that reason are calling this terrible album a masterpiece. Jamming with this guitarist must be the most frustrating thing in the universe but you'll appreciate that after listening to this because the whole album is basically a jam session that features an incredible drummer but otherwise musicians who are trying to be something they are not. In fact the drums are the most prominent instrument on this album. 5 stars for the drummer, 1 star for the insipid lyrics and non musical garbage of the rest of the album.

B0007GAEW6|5.0|Seldomly do I find an album that sits and shines next to my classics collection. Rare is it, that the album actually stays there for more than two weeks to a month. Aside from 2005 being one of the most explosive years in music since 1994, The Mars Volta cooked something that starts fire and sends fans either running or basking in the warmth.<br /><br />'Frances the Mute' is one of those albums that is a rare breed. There's a level of madness and to a degree that's somewhat glorifying and all out beautiful. Case in point,  \\"Cygnus...Vismund Cygnus.\\" An eye opener for anyone still left with \\"Televators\\" back in 2003. Spanish chords and Cedric's wispy, hollowed voice echoes like a lullaby until the band literally explodes to the point of seperation into a fast, catchy, riff riot. Think of the Big Bang theory, but do that in a politically correct way, too.<br /><br />Anyone who wants a second coming of Led Zeppelin's \\"Dazed and Confused\\", might be psyched(literally) with \\"The Widow.\\" Being the band's first single, it's only a three plate meal of the genuine banquet Volta has to offer. Cedric shines in this, but Omar seems rather styled even in a static, 'out of the henhouse' sort of way. There's beauty in style. I just think of blue lights and foggy roads, but that's me...<br /><br />\\"L'Via L'Viaquez\\" is a song I was at odds with. At first, I loved the heart attack riff that basically starts a Spanish fiesta, but for awhile I didn't understand why the song would be so basic. Verse, chorus, verse. Never did I think Mars Volta were capable of being this stoic, but I was wrong. Although I found the song eating my marrow, I also found it repetitive for some reason. Hell, I still skip to it today, though.<br /><br />More and more effects and an aura that either takes you to and from strange places or just pisses you off. I can't even begin to tell you how many people complained that they don't want to hear five minutes of static. It's not that, though.(So I explain, again.) It's a movement, it's a power that has no source. Ambience is about the one thing Mars Volta yearn to create and in the end, there's an atmosphere far more suitable than the burning sky today.<br /><br />\\"Cassandra Geminni\\" is why anyone should buy this album. In the thirty minute finale, this song plays like a hybrid, Paul Verhoeven/Oliver Stone love child film. There's the slow, the fast, the slow, and a lot of fastness back again. I would say controversial fastness...the type of fastness that can kill a man. What am I saying? There's no such thing as \\"fastness\\", but there's also no such thing as a thirty minute opus in this lifetime...<br /><br />But there is, but there is. When Cedric screams, \\"Now there's no light...\\", the drums kick and blast away a sound no different than the machine guns of a militaristic world. Omar basically makes love with his guitar and the band itself, especially organs and Spanish underlines(horns and sax), make this song probably one of the most important musical pieces in recent memory.<br /><br />You have a little of this, a lot of that, and a sum of all odds. Hell, that's exactly what this album is. Besides, my pick for 2005 Album of the Year.<br /><br />Not too shabby, not too shabby...again.) It's a movement, it's a power that has no source. Ambience is about the one thing Mars Volta yearn to create and in the end, there's an atmosphere far more suitable than the burning sky today. <br /> <br />\\"Cassandra Geminni\\" is why anyone should buy this album. In the thirty minute finale, this song plays like a hybrid, Paul Verhoeven/Oliver Stone love child film. There's the slow, the fast, the slow, and a lot of fastness back again. When Cedric screams, \\"Now there's no light...\\", the drums kick and blast away a sound no different than the machine guns of a militaristic world. Omar basically makes love with his guitar and the band itself, especially organs and Spanish underlines(horns and sax), make this song probably one of the most important musical pieces in recent memory. <br /> <br />You have a little of this, a lot of that, and a sum of all odds. B0000TB01Y|5.0|\\"Wicked\\" is a beautiful examination of the \\"Wizard of Oz\\" story, and tells it in a unique and effective way. I bought this CD as a result of a recommendation from a friend. It absolutely blew me away! <br />The main storyline of this musical is based upon the book by the same title, written by Gregory Maguire. It explores the history of Elfaba, a young woman destind to be known as the \\"Wicked Witch of the West\\" by the inhabitants of Oz. \\"Wicked\\" tells of Elfaba's childhood, how she was born as a result of an extramarital affair participated in by her mother and a travelling salesman. Elfaba is green as a result of her mother imbibing a green elixir while in the company of the salesman. Elfaba suffers ridicule and neglect from her mother and father, and is instructed to care for her younger sister Nessa, who is destined to become \\"The Wicked Witch of the East.\\" Elfaba and Nessa attend a school (Schizz,) for aspiring sorcerer's and sorceresses. While there, Elfaba is roommate with Golinda, (not a typo), who eventually becomes \\"The Witch of the North.\\" I will not give away anymore of the plot, I will just say that this musical explores innocence, idealism, and the struggle for exceptance as well as the lasting power of friendship. Not only does this musical have an interesting storyline, but it also has unsurpassable music! Stephen Schwartz, who wrote such hits as \\"Pippin,\\" \\"Godsspell,\\" and Children of Eden\\" is responsible for this gem. The cast is absolutely superb particularly Idena Menzel, who portrays Elfaba, (you may recognize her as the actress who portrayed Maurene in Rent,\\" and Kristin Chenoweth who portrays Golenda or Glenda. There duets together are stunning, and the supporting cast is equally beautiful, conveying the joy, fear and anger of the citizens of Oz and Schizz students. All the voice and orchestral music blends perfectly. Some unforgettable songs on this CD ar \\"Schizz,\\" \\"When I Meet the Wizard,\\" \\"Defying Gravity,\\" (by far the best song!) and \\"For Good.\\" This CD is a must-have. Everyone should give it a chance. Happy listening!

B0009VRHLK|4.0|After the critical acclaim of Buffalo '66, there was a certain amount of anticipation for what its writer/director/star Vincent Gallo would do next. He responded with The Brown Bunny, a film that, to put it mildly, polarized critics and audiences at the Cannes Film Festival. It met with harsh criticism and cited by some as the worst film ever to be shown in competition. This was largely in response to the film's notorious ending with co-star Chloe Sevigny and Gallo that outraged many. The film's deliberately slow pacing also didn't endear it to audiences. Gallo, not one to back down from a fight, engaged Roger Ebert in a highly publicized war of words that got quite nasty. Now that the dust has settled and the film has been quietly released on DVD, people can see for themselves what the fuss was all about.<br /><br />Stylistically, Gallo favours long, static takes, often holding on a shot for as long as he feels is necessary. In some respects, it's a throwback to the minimalist cinema of Monte Hellman, specifically Two-Lane Blacktop with its judicious use of dialogue and no frills production values. Gallo certainly has an ear for the right piece of music for the right scene, like the sad, wistful music of Gordon Lightfoot (\\"Beautiful\\") and Jackson C. Frank (\\"Milk & Honey\\") playing over shots of the road to create a particular mood.<br /><br />It would be so easy to dismiss Gallo's film as a vanity project run amok. After all, he wrote, directed, edited, produced, shot and stars in it. The Brown Bunny lacks Buffalo '66's humour and this seems to be a conscious decision on Gallo's part. In every respect, this movie is the antithesis to anything Hollywood is producing. Like Gus Van Sant's Gerry, Gallo's film is a cinematic endurance test-can you watch a man drive around for close to 90 minutes with the occasional interaction with other people? Yet, there is a certain poetry to The Brown Bunny, a certain simple beauty in observing every day things, like someone eating dinner or shopping for a rabbit or just driving cross-country. There are no intense car chases that defy physics or CGI-generated worlds.ng dinner or shopping for a rabbit or just driving cross-country. There are no intense car chases that defy physics or CGI-generated worlds.

B000060OFT|4.0|I think a lot of reviews of this film have been unduly harsh. I have had a fair amount of Shakespearean exposure (I was an English major in college), and I am actually impressed with Baz Luhrmann's interpretation of the text.  Some people are so blinded by the seeming erudite stuffiness of Shakespeare's work that they forget what this play is really about.  `Romeo and Juliet' is a teenage melodrama!  With that said, this film works well. <br />      <br />* To begin with, Leonardo DiCaprio and Clare Danes come off just right as the \\"star-crossed lovers.\\"  They handle their lines - perhaps - a bit awkwardly, and their key scenes are overacted.  But as far as I'm concerned, their somewhat `poor' performances are actually perfect.  In the reality of the play - Romeo and Juliet's behavior (though arguably passionate) is less than genuine.  They are young, fickle, and full of hormones, and what might seem like acts of heart-felt love and desire are actually just curious explorations of subversive behavior.  <br /> <br />* Many have lamented that the dialogue in this film (essentially) mirrors the original text ... but changing the text (in any major way) would be a huge mistake.  Shakespeare's plays are not famous because they have a great story line - they are famous because of the unbelievable writing.  It would, therefore, be pointless to modernize the dialogue.  Shakespeare's plays ARE the dialogue.  <br /> <br />* Although this film - compared with other renditions of the play - is decidedly modern, certain elements do contribute to a sort of timely ambiguity.  The cars, guns, drugs, and music suggest 1996 (or thereabouts), whereas the gothic mansions, the ball, the feuding families, and the oppressive presence of the Church seem somewhat anachronistic.  I think this ambiguity speaks to the universality of Shakespeare's work.  Does it even matter when this play takes place?  Have hot-blooded teenagers changed that much over the years?  <br /> <br />* Lastly, the ambience of Lurhmann's film is intoxicating: zipping, choppy cinematography, an over-abundance of gaudy electric lighting, and an intriguing soundtrack.  It's very titillating in an adolescent sort of way.  Anyone who does not find the scene - where DiCaprio is dragging on a cigarette against an orangey sunscape, with Radiohead's \\"Talk Show Host\\" slowly pulsing in the background - sentimentally sexy - well, you must not remember what it's like to be 15.    <br /> <br />All in all, this is an ingenious approach to a classic text - not to mention an entertaining film.

B000AL730O|5.0|Chaos and Creation (C+C) is an unprecedented success for solo Paul; as he has fully come to terms with Beatle Paul, his fellow Beatles and the 21st Century to cast a verbal tapestry upon this hard of hearing, weary world.    Re-arrange the tracks in the following order and add the 2 single B-sides of the single Fine Line to fully appreciate a thematic/concept munument of sound, words and emotions.    Start with Anyway.  This sets a tone/mood more reflective of the whole.  This invites us to \\" make yourselves at home.\\"   This \\"curing of sorrows\\" is about transitions in his life and meeting John, Linda and Heather - and for our intimates - anyway....  then the jam/coda sparkles and cracks with a preview of the kaleidescope of sonics and tuneful creations to wash over us.       Too Much Rain follows; obviously John was present in his mind and psyche; \\"wheels keep turning (\\"watching the....\\"), lamenting how they'd \\"hide their feelings\\", and \\"won't happen again.\\" John wrote \\"Rain\\" and layed out the theme of perception and dealing with those rainy feelings.    Promise to You should come next with Paul playing the Sun King here, with his Revolver personna Good-Day Sunshine/Get You Into My Life bleached soul.  Exploding with Man-Woman exuberant love - plus his declarations of Universal Love for all in the world to hear and soak in the vibes.    Friends to Go - Yes George' influence is heavy, as is the theme of seeking comfort in the afterlife (the \\"other-side\\") for his dearly departed.  Even joy, as the horns of \\"All You Need is Love\\" crows off in the distance of the music mix.    Follow this with Growing up Falling Down and English Tea, two White Album offspring showing off his versatility and creativity.  \\"Growing Up\\" is very haunting as I can see George, John and Ringo swaying, smiling and enthralled with this Beatle-esque bubbling brew ( circa 1969?) song they seem to have ALL co-written.  (this is as close as we can hope for).    Jenny Wrenn; sing \\"Heather Mills\\" overJenny's name and the song is self-evident.    Next song: Certain Softness. Growing in love with his wife's apparant surprising complexities and textures inspires Paul on his next song to Heather and her \\"certain sadness\\" and \\"touch of wildness.\\"  He's nakedly smitten - and honest.    Next: Follow Me.  This is about John, higher power, God, friends?  All?  Open to different shades of meaning, but you gotta believe he thought this after meeting John and traveling, playing with the Beatles and having John  lead the boys in their chant of \\"To the top of the toppermost.\\"  Follow Me, they did.    Next:  This never happened to me Before.  But it happened for Paul, more than once, and he appreciates it in this inspired love tome.      Fine Line:  This is towards the end of the Fab Four, when EVERYBODY left the group a time or two  and he wishes they could have solved the problems with a rocker like this.  \\"All is forgiven, come back, come back.\\"  Indeed, Get Back, it was a painful time.    How Kind  should follow here, how the aged wizened boys would treat each other now.    Round out with At the Mercy and Vanity Fair, but be sure to include the B-side roockfest: \\"Comfort of Love\\" in-between; it's all about: having it all except - voila! - \\"CAN'T BUY ME LOVE !!!  This propulsive rock n' roll song is what the album needs and validates the fan's pleas for such on this CD.  Add this and the problem is solved. B0000009RX|5.0|Literally. The Greatest Album In The History Of Music. I've listened to this so much I can replay the entire thing in my head and I know all the weird background noises and inside jokes and everything. <br /> <br />You probably know about the hippie-bashing on this album but it goes into much more than that: horrible parents, drinking, government, cops and of course boogers kept in jars. (And yes I'm serious.) Zappa and The M.O.I. weren't pro-war or against love. They we're against how the hippies spreading their message by not actually doing anything, just complaining and smoking pot. <br /> <br />Although some of it is humorous, there's always an underlying truth and creepiness to the message. Check out the harmony in \\"Concetration Moon\\", \\"Don't cry, gotta go bye-bye, suddenly die, die. Cop kill a creep. Pow, pow, pow!\\" <br /> <br />The album will sound like a mess at first especially with all the complex musicianship on it and weird noises and studio effects. Check it out with headphones to see what I mean. (You gotta listen to the absoulutely beautiful opening piano solo on \\"Absolutely Free\\") The album is literally filled with odd breaks in-between songs and during them that won't make sense at first but you get you realize the genius of it all like a non-stop symphony. <br /> <br />The songs are weird but catchy like \\"What's The Ugliest Part Of Your Body?\\" which is probably won't seem like a song you wouldn be humming for days if you just read the title. <br /> <br />Things to check out during the album: <br />-Eric Clapton's cameo on \\"Are You Hung Up?\\" <br />-The messed up take on \\"Hey Joe\\" on Flower Punk <br />-The surf music at the end of \\"Nasal Retentive Calliope Music\\" which is a song by The Rotations called \\"Heavies\\" which Frank produced early in the '60s and can be bought on the \\"Frank Zappa: Cucamonga\\" compilation. <br /> <br />Seriously, I was skeptic, too, after hearing about this album even after the first 1 or 2 listens you probably won't really digit but it is DEFINITELY worth it. You'll be saying you're the \\"Indian Of The Group\\" after a while.
B000AL730O|4.0|There aren't many peolple alive (or dead, just one or two) who'd tell Sir Paul McCartney former Beatle that some of his submissions for a new album were naff.  But Sir George Martins' suggestion of Nigel Godrich, the producer who turned Radiohead from miserablists to legends, was more than just inspired. <br />Nigel Godrich refused, point blank, some of the songs Paul brought to these sessions.  Looking back there's so many times McCartney could have used producers like this, his last true classic (Tug Of War 1982) was produced by George Martin, The Beatles' own in-house producer. <br />It seems that Sir Paul is not yet ready to raise a snobby nostril and tell an upstart to leave.  The first thing most Mccartney fans will notice is there are no 'paper bag over the head' moments of twee embarrasment to be had here.  The closest contender being the Noel Coward pastiche 'English Tea', that turns out to be just...fun, like 'When I'm 64'.  Not agood song, just fun. <br />Throughout Paul is reined in from sugary-saccharine sweetness, turning songs like 'Riding To Vanity Fair' from pure schlock to beautiful compositions with haunting backdrops, and giving tracks like 'Fine Line' and 'Friend To go' a sense of fun lacking in his music for 23 years. <br />B****y Hell! I've been listening to every word this man has uttered for 24 years! <br />Maybe I should get a life. <br />Then again if this album is an idea of future utterances, then maybe I should listen a while longer.

B000AL730O|5.0|This album had an unusual effect on me.  Normally I have avoided Sir Paul's solo efforts like the plague- not wanted to be reminded of how difficult it has been for someone (with so much talent) to find it so difficult to live up to the standard of his work during the 60's.  I'm not saying he 'lost' his talent since the break up of the beatles, but it has just been criminally hard i guess, to live up to the impossible high expectations of the beatles.  Sir Paul doesn't have to change the world anymore, he's already done that once, so why should he need to prove himself to the nasty critics who always compare him unfavourably to his old band mate.  You can't change the world twice with the same style of music anyway I say.   <br /> <br />I listened to this new album all the way through, without looking away from my computer screen.  I can't get through the first three tracks on most albums these days: so much filler, so little talent, so much imitation, so many 'hacks' and worse, so much false and empty innovation.  So, on that alone, I guess that I must have enjoyed it.  But because it's paul mccartney, it's almost impossible to be objective (not that we should have to anyway) about his work- it's been copied so many times and is just so 'written in stone' that I think most critics *can't* actually review it fairly.  As soon as I hear his voice, I am seven years old, sitting at my dad's stereo with headphones on, listening to my beatles collection.  Makes it very hard to actually 'hear' these songs. <br /> <br />So I played a little game:  I was imagining that it wasn't paul mccartney, but some new songwriter from england.  Let's call him 'eric wangler'.   <br /> <br />Holy crap.  Eric knows how to write a song!  I thought the first song was decent, but they got better and better!  Mr. wangler understands the form of the pop song perfectly.  He knows how to craft a beautiful melody, but avoids melodic cliche by providing just enough variation.  He knows how to staywithin the verse chorus verse structure, yet doesn't follow it slavishly, and not one song is the same form-wise: always a little suprise when you feel tedium about to set in. Most songwriters thing they HAVE to go to the second chorus after the second verse.  Wangler steers clear of such formula.  <br /> <br />Harmonically, his chord progressions are quite striking-  he stays within the pop idiom, yet innovates harmonically more than most pop writers.  Diminished runs, baroque progressions, odd little chromatic modulations.  Really very clever. Wangler does the twee beatles pop thing (i think he must like the bealtes), but in a genuine way that avoids the vocal double tracking, flanging, mellotrons, timpani and pantsy fluff that EVERY other band uses when they try to sound like the beatles (and pretend that it was an original).  Eric evokes that era, without any effects.  A guitar, piano, stripped down drumkit and a sincere vocal.  A flute and some strings at most are the only other additions.  Try that elliot and mr. finn.  <br /> <br />Lyrically, eric stays simple, but heartfelt.  It would be easy to go of on an overly complicated overblown costello-like crusade of literary pretensions, attempting to match the 'wit' of the music, but he keeps the lyrics simple- even if at times he sounds uncertain- it adds to the charm.  kudo eric, kudos. <br /> <br /> The production is beautifully simple and warm.  Eric plays all of the instruments, and the same intimacy that stevie wonder managed on his early 70's albums is achieved (WHY did he hire other musician? oh why?) <br />  <br />This eric fellow might go far.  WHAT?  he's 62 years old?  holy...ok...that's weird. well, this old dude is keeping it real!  He outclassed most other songwriters around now. By the time he's 70 he might be able to get a band. <br /> <br />Well done mr. wangler.  Well done. <br /> <br />Mirko Ruckels <br /> <br />

0743526937|4.0|Getting to Yes started a revolution in negotiation, both by stressing principled negotiation and in making the material accessible to a very wide audience.  It is still a good read, is still taught in universities and continuing education, and is an excellent starting point for people who are new to negotiation but intend a deep study because of its historical significance and its content.<br /><br />However, having taught Getting to Yes and having used principled bargaining in practice, I think there are a few shortcomings that are dealt with in other books.  While Fischer and Ury do make the point that principled bargaining includes sticking to your priciples and not being a pushover, it is not emphasized enough.  I have even found myself being too cooperative after reviewing this text because the emphasis is on being cooperative.  I think this is a partcular danger for new/lay negotiators, especially if this is the first text they're exposed to or they intend to practice these concepts in daily life.  The tone of the book is just a bit too friendly.  As a result, there has been a backlash (wrongly, in my opinion) against this text in some quarters.<br /><br />The verbal judo section at the end is excellent, giving techniques for dealing with unreasonable people that are great.  I would've liked more of these very practical tips and examples to go along with them, but the book as a whole is already a lot to digest.  Newer versions of GTY do add more material here.<br /><br />Newer texts take these problems into account.  The best, in my opinion, is the follow-on by Ury, \\"Getting Past No.\\"  It can be read without having read \\"Getting to Yes,\\" although it is very interesting as a follow-on, too.  In it, Ury is clearly taking into account the criticism that GTY was too soft and he presents a more robust vision of principled bargaining.
0425173739|3.0|A trip to Egypt, a cruise up the Nile and a visit to the Cataract Hotel in Aswan last year prompted me to read Agatha Christie's famous detective novel, \\"Death on the Nile.\\" Apparently, the author wrote the novel while staying in the famous Cataract Hotel. <br /> <br />This is the first murder mystery by Christie that I have read. I was hoping for a little bit more detail and information about where the story took place - Egypt, the Nile, local culture and customs, and tourism in that region during the early part of the 20th century. However, the author barely touched on any of those topics throughout her story. Instead, she focused on character development, personal conflicts and relationship dynamics while planting clues as the story progressed into the who-done-it that she is famous for. Even though I enjoyed the pace and writing style of the book, I was a bit disappointed at the end having not learned a thing about Egypt. It's a good thing that I have been there to know where the story took place. <br /> <br />The Cataract Hotel is one of the most beautifully decorated and astonishingly architected buildings that I have ever seen. The ceilings seem to extend to the sky, whose primary function I assume is to act as a receptacle for the often unbearable heat that suffocates the area. It proudly stands on top of a giant hill overlooking the River Nile and a Genghis Khan Mausoleum that sits on the opposite bank of the river. This hotel is definitely one to be seen. For as astounding as it is, and the simple fact that Christie actually stayed there, it is very surprising that she neglected to describe its exquisiteness in this book.

B000AL730O|3.0|This is a good album, but not as great as all the accolades. Yes, it is interesting. Yes, it is darker. Yes, it is well produced. And yet, it's still not as great as it could have been. Anyone following Paul McCartney's career knows he's been on the ascent for some time now. His songwriting skills have improved, his singing, his phenomenal band, the live shows... It seemed he was poised for a great album. Chaos is a side step. Nigel Godrich made him bring songs that attempted emotional resonance. That's a good thing and very needed in McCartney's work, but he still didn't push him past the simplistic, self-explanatory, dad by the campfire, lyrics (AKA: bad writing).  This undermines the great melodies that abound in this album. A great song has to not only be note perfect, but word perfect. One bum line can sink it. And often it's only one or two lines where McCartney needs to go poetic (in the modern fragmented sense) and instead goes sing-song, (Note: Riding to Vanity Fair, This Never Happened Before, Too Much Rain). Sometimes it's more than a couple lines, (Follow Me, At the Mercy, Anyway, Jenny Wren). What he needs, if not just told that \\"it's not good enough,\\" is someone to assist him with lyrics.  <br /> <br />Also, Nigel Godrich has insisted we want an album that sounds like Paul McCartney. True, but what we really want is the songwriter who appeared on Abbey Road, Let It Be and the White Album. No, the middle eight of Tug of War is not Paul at his best. And though this album is far superior to Tug of War, I can't help noticing that the slick production is causing people to believe this is McCartney of old, as they did with that album. Also, Nigel, bossa nova is not Paul's strong suit (Certain Softness)... how about a great ROCK album? A few great rock songs, (their germination evident on Driving Rain), in addition to good pop songs (A Fine Line, Promise to You Girl), those moody tracks, and just good songs regardless of category (How Kind of You: still somebum lines, damn it!) and you'll have a great album. For now, we're left to take the best of Chaos and Driving Rain and make a good compilation. That's no small thing, but for an unequivocal return-to-form, a la Time Out of Mind, we still have to wait...  <br />

0765310015|4.0|The book was good from the first page, but not interesting until about halfway through. Erikson did not do enough to bring his characters to life and so there was no emotional attachment whatsoever to any of the characters. This makes the book a bit boring and difficult to read. It's like he starts explaining a complicated situation, then he introduces the players, and then the reasons for the parts they play in this complicated situation which you are still trying to understand (It should be the other way round).  <br />Also, considering that there was a war going on, there wasn't enough actual fighting.  <br />What I do think is really original, though, is the way magic is used in this book. I really like the world Erikson created; enough wizardry and magical creatures to make it a fantasy novel, but containing a good amount of similarities to the world we know from our own history books. It's also interesting that the women are taken to be equal to the men. <br />If you like George Martin, you'll probably like Erikson although he's not nearly as good. <br />On the whole, it was a very good book and I look forward to reading the next one.

0060512806|3.0|The devotee of Athena can quite nearly craft a great novel. <br /> <br />It's so close to greatness.  So frustratingly close. <br /> <br />The thing is, most of his normal audience already know the coding theory and the discussions of science.  So, this stuff doesn't belong in conversational didaction.  It belongs in an afterword, or a footnote. <br /> <br />The style of writing is very sprawling and loose and conversational.  This is an exceptionally American male manner of writing.  Unlike King, however, Stephenson seems to be following not some small-town patience, but a deep intellects powerful mental ability to wander off topic and quickly return in real time, though the mind has gone off for pages.  Does that make sense?   <br /> <br />Basically, fans of Stephen King will be right at home.  Both authors have a lot in common.  They deal in an imaginative speculative genre, with lots of characters, and a strong grasp for said characters' personalities.  They have very strong stomachs.  They are \\"cool\\" in their own way. <br /> <br />Artistically, however, this also creates a problem.  I think a long flashback about dental work in the middle of a passionate reunion with the main character's girlfriend inside a brutal Phillipine prison is a little too much.  I don't care about the dentist!  I care about the girl! <br /> <br />It's so close.  I'd hate to edit it too much, especially in the beginning, but if he could've just taken a red pen over the last hundred-fifty pages and cut them in half... <br /> <br />Athena was the goddess of defensive war and invention, and she was the chosen muse for this epic.  I am reminded of the end of the Oddessey, when the story just keeps going and going and Oddesseus is in the middle of this field staring down his citizens in dress armor and we can't help but feel that the poem ended a few hundred lines ago yet the story still moves on.  This book ends the same way.  It just keeps going and going and the resolution doesn't feel like a resolution.  The real resolution was pages ago, in Goto Dengo's Japanese power tower. <br /> <br />So close.  So close.  Still, if you like a Stephen King tome now and then, you'll probably enjoy this author as well. <br /> <br />Many like to make Thomas Pynchon comparisons.  The Pynchon comparisons are more apt with The Baroque Cycle.  Comparing Pynchon's masterpiece Mason & Dixon to the Baroque Cycle reminds one of the strengths and weaknesses of both of these modern American masters.  Pynchon's too disciplined and stoned.  Stephenson's too sober and loose.  I'd love to see those two write the same short story from the same outline.  That's a book I'd buy, for sure.

6304119046|5.0|Cinematography: Toland was at the top of his game, and Welles was lucky to have so experienced an eye behind the camera.  Think expressive, meaningful angles, shadows, deep-focus shots--they're all there, a veritable textbook of technique. <br /> <br />Music: Herrmann, like most on the set a newcomer to Hollywood, broke the mold of German Romanticism (Korngold, Steiner).  Arguably this is his best film score, although Vertigo's up there too.  Particularly great moments: the snow music that suddenly goes from gorgeous to sarcastic; the clever waltz variations underscoring the darkening mood of the breakfast scene; the aria (which has been recorded stupendously by Kiri Te Kanawa, although in the film it deliberately isn't put over so successfully); and the way the main theme is hurled at you at the climax--always gets me. <br /> <br />Editing: Such energy & innovation here, particularly in the newsreel (a brilliant parody) & the rapid segues leading from Susan's apartment to the campaign speech. <br /> <br />Acting: Most of the cast had plenty of stage experience which translated into fresh dramatic power on the screen.  Cotten & Moorehead turned in better performances later, but Sloane, Collins, & Comingore are at their best here, and Welles's own performace is simply towering. <br /> <br />Make Up: Poor Welles had to get started at 2 a.m. everytime he wanted to shoot an \\"old-age\\" scene, but what they achieved here still holds up against anything today. <br /> <br />Narrative Structure: Welles started out shooting Heart of Darkness, and when the funding for that project dried up the one thing he carried over to Kane was the flashback structure, which has influenced so many things since, from classic film noir to Pulp Fiction. <br /> <br />Themes: All the brilliant devices are there not for their own sake but to serve the subject matter, a tragic story that takes on some big themes about society & private life, and it's this matching of form & content that really makes the film so enduringly great. <br />
